column1: # Lines starting with '#' are comments and will be ignored by the parser.
# 1. Name                    - Unique identifier for the protease
# 2. Motif                   - Cleavage motif syntax defining where cleavage occurs (see below)
# 3. Specificity             - One of: full, semi, none, SingleN, SingleC
# 5. PSI-MS Name             - Standard name from PSI-MS ontology
# 6. Cleavage Modification   - Name of modification applied at cleavage site (optional)
# The motif syntax uses a simple pattern language:
#   |     = Cleavage point (where the peptide bond is cut)
#   A-Z   = Specific amino acid (single letter code)
#   K[P]| = Cleave after K, UNLESS followed by P
#          (prevents cleavage when P is C-terminal to K)
#   "K[P]|,R[P]|" = Cleave after K or R, unless followed by P
#   GPX{P}|GPX{P} = Match GPX|GPX pattern, but X cannot be P
# Trypsin:     "K[P]|,R[P]|"  - Cleaves after K or R, not before P
# Asp-N:       |D             - Cleaves before D (N-terminal to D)
# Lys-C:       K[P]|          - Cleaves after K, not before P
# Non-specific: X|            - Cleaves after any residue
# full    - Both termini must match cleavage rules
# semi    - Only one terminus must match cleavage rules
# SingleN - Single cleavage, N-terminal fragments only
# SingleC - Single cleavage, C-terminal fragments only
